posts.cooked:
a person, who decides to store his photos in google photos, cannot be helped anymore. this person has no understanding of privacy, he even has no problem to let google participate on very private moments of his life.
all users of the signal messenger are very focused on the privacy of their contents, and I doubt, that there is anyone, who is using signal and saving his photos in google photos. because clearly, that behaviour wouldn’t make any sense.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

all users of the signal messenger are very focused on the privacy of their contents, and I doubt, that there is anyone, who is using signal and saving his photos in google photos. because clearly, that behaviour wouldn’t make any sense.

Very bold statement. I’m sure plenty of Signal users use Google Photos, Drive, Dropbox, iCloud or one of the many other cloud services. We have decided that we want our photos backed up on the cloud so that’s what we do.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

Very bold statement. I’m sure plenty of Signal users use Google Photos, Drive, Dropbox, iCloud or one of the many other cloud services. We have decided that we want our photos backed up on the cloud so that’s what we do.

no really, i don’t get that.
photos are much more personal then written text. so people saving their photos and videos in google photos means: they don’t care, if others can see those photos.
so why would one of these google-photos-user chose signal to send a photo to someone else? doesn’t make any sense to me. i would use google mail or hangouts or facebook then.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: It’s an individual choice. You don’t need to decide for everyone.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

so people saving their photos and videos in google photos means: they don’t care, if others can see those photos.

This is correct. I’m assuming you don’t have any social media accounts where you share pictures of yourself or family and that’s totally fine, but there are plenty of people that do. I have no issue putting my photos there and I have no issue posting a photo on my Instagram or Facebook.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

no really, i don’t get that.
photos are much more personal then written text.

Agree to disagree. Things you say are much more harmful than almost any image. I use Signal because I want my messages to be between me and my recipient; I want no outside party viewing my messages. I also want Instant Messaging for the fact that Instant Messaging is great.

I’ve noticed that some people on the forum seem to think that Signal is all about being 100% private, meaning no outside services at all (for example Google Services) but that isn’t the case. From what I’ve heard and read, Signal is about offering privacy and security to the average user (since everyone sends messages). It isn’t about being off the grid completely.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

why would one of these google-photos-user chose signal to send a photo to someone else?

Not all photos are created equal. I am one of those Signal users who also stores some photos in the cloud with Google Photos. However, there are certain photos that I only send through Signal and do not save to my device, nor do I share them to Google Photos.

@Herohtar @Tursko

have u ever thought of using tresorit as cloud service?

Attach photos from Google Photos?

This is correct. I’m assuming you don’t have any social media accounts what so ever where you share pictures of yourself or family and that’s totally fine

actually I share alot of photos. I shot them, they are saved on my iphone, and then I send them to others with signal, whatsapp, threema or sometimes via airdrop. I never missed a cloud solution…

Attach photos from Google Photos?

have u ever thought of using tresorit as cloud service?

I have not but I’ll check it out. I mainly use Google cloud services because it allows me to have everything in one place. I have my important files on Drive, I have emails on Gmail, and I have photos on Google Photos. Very convenient on my Google phone haha.

Attach photos from Google Photos?

I have not but I’ll check it out. I mainly use Google cloud services because it allows me to have everything in one place.

i follow exactly the opposite strategy.
i use an iphone, my computer runs with windows, i use signal and whatsapp and others and my email provider is a small local one. noone shall know too much. I don’t use a cloud service for private things (just for job).

Attach photos from Google Photos?

I have my important files on Drive, I have emails on Gmail, and I have photos on Google Photos. Very convenient on my Google phone haha.

so you are a really privacy guy. important files on drive, gmail…
i wonder where the really privacy gurus are? they are not here, they either died out, or they use something else. but what?

Attach photos from Google Photos?

so you are a really privacy guy. important files on drive, gmail…

I say important, but what I mean is things that I need to have access to at anytime. So things like documents, projects and so on. And no where here did I claim I was a ‘privacy guy’. Anything that I truly think is private IS NOT on a cloud service and is instead on some type of physical storage that I own.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
tascha:

my computer runs with windows

You follow some kind of “privacy-first” strategy? LOL

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: Another online service that is zero-knowledge is sync.com. It has its foibles but is decent.

awaitlink:

You follow some kind of “privacy-first” strategy? LOL

hello McFly; the main thing for people like you seems to be: in any case make some stupid comment, and, most important, without knowing anything about the background. And: don’t think.

actually I need a computer, not only for private matters, also, because I have to work on it. the choice is: mac or windows.

both OS are not the best choice for privacy, for security windows might be the better choice right now. windows (<10) is not so bad as most people thing, if you know which things to add in the registry and which services not to run.

basically the privacy part about this is, not giving one company (for instance google), too much information about yourself. having e-mail, contacts, calendar, documents, photos, maybe google pay, and thus all financial transactions to one company is the worst thing you can do, it’s always better to spread information as much as possible.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
tascha:

some stupid comment

This phrase of you below is stupid too in my opinion.

But you can’t generalize that immediately to “in any case” and jump to the conclusion that someone doesn’t think at all when writing.

tascha:

all users of the signal messenger are very focused on the privacy of their contents, and I doubt, that there is anyone, who is using signal and saving his photos in google photos

tascha:

it’s always better to spread information as much as possible.

If you spread information, then there are a lot of services and dependencies, and since you don’t (and wouldn’t want to) have a centralized management system for that, it obviously becomes harder to manage.

In my opinion, it’s the balance between usefulness and privacy that has to be kept.

I’m torn on this. Not for myself personally, but for someone I am trying to get to use Signal. They aren’t upgrading their iPhone until it has a 5G chip. But the storage on their phone now is super low, in the hundreds of megabytes. I have backed up their photos to multiple storage drives, but for them its not feasible to be personally transferring, accessing, manipulating when they want a certain photo from a specific time.

iCloud would probably be their best option if they are bent on cloud storage. But its going to cost money. At first its not that much for the 50gb plan, but who knows what happens as it continues to grow. Google Photos is obviously super-convenient for a lot of people, but there are some privacy concerns. They do have Amazon Prime so Amazon Photos is a possibility. There is definitely some privacy concerns with that too. Amazon Photos does allow unlimited storage of all photos but only 5gb for video, while Google allows unlimited for photos up to 16 megapixels and 1080p video. So both have some pluses and minuses.

I am wondering if Amazon would be less likely to be intrusive in harvesting information compared to Google since its a paid service. Any thoughts? I suppose iCloud would be the most secure and private for them. The only issue is the cost, but in reality its not that big of an issue at the 50gb (.99 per month) or 200gb (2.99 per month) level.

I mention these 3 services because realistically they are their only options as they need something extremely simplistic and easy to have access to on a couple of their devices.

Honestly I still think Google Photos is your best bet if they want it to be free. Everything else is just preference. When it comes to iCloud, 50gb is A LOT of photos and as long as they clear out all the unnecessary junk I’m sure it will last them a decent amount of time.

Apple & Google > Amazon (but still Amazon is probably just fine).

One thing to mention is that they can always download those photos off of the cloud service. So once they hit that 50gb max they could take everything off and throw it on a physical drive. Which then would essentially reset their 50gb.

i would buy some external storage, which you can connect to the lightning port of the iphone. there are thousands of different available. you can move photos to this external storage, and wait for the new iphone.

just one example:
https://www.amazon.de/SanDisk-Flash-Laufwerk-kompatibel-automatisches-flexibler/dp/B01CIEBXZG?psc=1&SubscriptionId=AKIAILSHYYTFIVPWUY6Q&tag=duc03-21&linkCode=xm2&camp=2025&creative=165953&creativeASIN=B01CIEBXZG

this is easy to handle, and for sure better for your privacy than moving private photos to a cloud storage.
